title: Perfect Square
content: A natural number n is a perfect square if n = m² for some natural m.

title: Square Product Property
content: A subset S of the interval {n+1,...,n+t} has the square product property if n·∏S is a perfect square.

title: The Function t_n
content: t_n is the minimal t such that {n+1,...,n+t} contains a subset whose product with n is a perfect square. If n is already a square, t_n = 0.

title: Example: t_6 = 6
content: t_6 = 6 because 6·8·12 = 576 = 24². The subset {8, 12} ⊆ {7,...,12} makes 6 times the product a perfect square.

title: Largest Prime Divisor P(n)
content: P(n) denotes the largest prime factor of n. The trivial lower bound t_n ≥ P(n) holds because we need another multiple of P(n) to cancel odd prime powers.

title: Selfridge's Theorem
content: When P(n) > √(2n) + 1, we have t_n = P(n) exactly. Otherwise, t_n ≤ O(√n). This completely characterizes t_n based on the size of the largest prime factor.

title: Lower Bound for All Non-Squares
content: For all non-square n ≥ 3: t_n ≥ C·(log log n)^{6/5}/(log log log n)^{1/5}. This shows t_n grows at least as a power of log log n.

title: Bui-Pratt-Zaharescu (2024)
content: The distribution of t_n follows P(n)'s distribution: for any fixed c ∈ (0,1], among n with P(n) ≤ n^c, we have t_n = P(n) for almost all such n.

title: Smooth and Rough Numbers
content: y-smooth numbers have all prime factors ≤ y. For smooth n, t_n is small (≤ y). For rough n (large P(n)), we have t_n = P(n) exactly.

title: Complete Characterization of t_n
content: t_n is completely characterized: (1) t_n ≥ P(n) always, (2) t_n = P(n) when P(n) > √(2n)+1, (3) t_n ≤ O(√n) otherwise. The behavior depends on whether n is 'rough' or 'smooth'.
